newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: FOCUS-Singapore GDP growth seen at 6.4 pct in 1996.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Singapore GDP growth seen at 6.4 pct in 1996.

text.p: Singapore's economy is likely to grow by only 6.4 percent this year, compared with 8.8 percent in 1995 and 10.2 percent in 1994, a Reuters' poll of leading financial institutions suggested on Tuesday.

The poll of 11 economists, carried out after Monday's announcement of a surprise 6.2 percent fall in the island's non-oil exports in September, shows estimates are still being cut to reflect the current slump in global electronics demand.
Electronics, computers and related products account for about 50 percent of Singapore's total industrial production and almost 60 percent of its non-oil exports.
A similar Reuters poll last week forecast Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) would grow by 6.5 percent this year. A poll in September forecast 1996 growth at 7.1 percent.
But Monday's non-oil export figures were at the bottom of expectations and encouraged several economists to cut their forecasts for 1996 growth by as much as 0.5 percentage point.
"The trade numbers were worse than I thought," said Liew Yin Sze, economist at local brokerage J.M. Sassoon. "The electronics sector was bad and almost every other sector was also weaker."
Monday's figures showed a 23.7 percent year-on-year fall in Singapore's exports of telecommunication equipment and a 16.2 percent fall in exports of electrical machinery.
But it also showed a 20 percent year-on-year decline in exports of crude materials and a 10.8 percent fall in drinks and tobacco products.

The result of the latest Reuters poll contrasts with Singapore's most recent official forecast, restated by Trade and Industry Minister Yeo Cheow Tong as recently as September 24, of "seven to eight percent" growth for 1996.
One economist said he expected the government to cut its official growth forecast for the year sometime over the next few weeks, probably at its quarterly economic briefing in mid-November.
The poll left the average forecast for Singapore's GDP in 1997 unchanged at 7.0 percent year-on-year.

Many economists said they had not had time to readjust fully their quarterly growth estimates in light of the recent trade data, but several shaved their forecasts by a few tenths of a percentage point.
Most now expect Singapore's GDP growth in the third quarter to average slightly over 3.0 percent year-on-year. Growth in the fourth quarter was expected to average around 4.9 percent.

Eddie Lee, economist at brokerage Vickers Ballas, said he had adjusted downwards his forecast for Singapore's growth this year, but still expected a strong rebound in 1997 when the current electronics downturn was over.
"I am looking for a full recovery next year," he said.
